newsitem.title: USA: Booming demand overseas shrinks U.S. trade gap.
newsitem.headline: Booming demand overseas shrinks U.S. trade gap.

text.p: Robust foreign demand for American-made aircraft and other goods narrowed the U.S. trade deficit sharply in March as it gave the economy added impetus, the Commerce Department reported on Wednesday.

The shortfall between exports and imports tumbled 19 percent from February to $8.51 billion, the smallest gap since $7.97 billion last November. The closely watched bilateral deficit with China was the lowest in nearly a year.
Analysts said the better-than-expected March performance meant the U.S. economy was churning forward at an even brisker first-quarter pace than previously thought, straining to meet orders.
"It smells like 6 percent," said Commerce Undersecretary Everett Ehrlich, referring to a likely upward revision in the annual rate of growth in first-quarter gross domestic product.
That would represent a pickup from the already vigorous 5.6 percent rate of first-quarter expansion in GDP reported a month ago.

During March total exports increased 4.1 percent from February to a record $76.48 billion. Imports grew by a more modest 1.2 percent from February to $84.99 billion, also a record, kept in check by a lower value of imported cars and parts, primarily from Canada.

The contraction in the deficit occurred despite a higher-valued dollar that made U.S. goods more costly for foreigners to buy and amid relatively lackluster overseas economies in Japan and much of Western Europe.
"We produce the goods that the rest of the world wants, particularly in high-tech and aircraft," economist Mike Fenollosa of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co. said.
"What's more we are able to sell them even though the dollar is high and foreign economies are struggling," he added, so the export picture should brighten further if foreign economies improve.

A day after the Clinton administration announced it was extending China's most-favored-nation trading status, the Commerce Department said the March bilateral deficit with the Asian trade dynamo plummeted 22.4 percent to $2.59 billion -- the lowest since $2.3 billion in April last year.
But the deficit with Japan swelled to $4.61 billion, an 8.3 percent increase from February's $4.26 billion gap.
Persistent deficits with Japan seem unending.

In April numbers released on Monday, Tokyo said that its bilateral surplus with the United States more than doubled last month, on a year-over-year basis, largely because of surging exports. Japan's exports have been fueled by a weaker yen that makes its goods attractive in foreign markets.
Ehrlich indicated the Clinton administration wants more action from Japan to curb its supluses, especially since new consumption taxes on April 1 may dampen Japanese consumers' taste for imports.
"Our concern ... is that Japan will revert to a pattern of allowing the rest of the world to pull it out of a cyclical downturn," Ehrlich said.
Previously, the department said the February deficit was $10.42 billion. But it revised that up to $10.54 billion.

The cost of imported crude oil fell for a second consecutive month during March, down 4 percent to $4.38 billion, as the price per barrel eased to $18.72 from $20.49 in February and from $22.03 in January.
The United States typically runs a surplus on its trade with other countries in services like travel and tourism, which partly offsets big merchandise trade deficits.
In March the merchandise deficit fell 11.4 percent from February to $15.06 billion. The surplus on services climbed 1.3 percent to $6.56 billion.
In trade with Mexico, the United States posted a deficit of $1.47 billion in March, more than a 20 percent jump from February's $1.2 billion shortfall.
The United States had a smaller surplus on trade with Western Europe of $320 million in March, compared with $330 million in February.

Foreign sales of civilian aircraft jumped strongly in March to $2.46 billion from $1.72 billion in February. Commerce officials said much of the gain was accounted for by stronger sales to South Korea and to Saudi Arabia.
Imports of autos and parts from all sources fell by $1.22 billion to $11.09 billion in March from $12.31 billion in February while consumer goods imports eased by $98 million to $15.14 billion.
